ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about translation, and was first exposed to it as a site of ideological contestation and complexity. I also learned how to make decisions in my own translation project and how to consider the theory we studied in an applied setting.
Overview of the major theories, debates, and practices relating to translation.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really enjoyed this course, and I think that its greatest strength was how it brought together theory and application. I was really glad to be translating as I read the theory in the course, because the practice helped me better understand the theory and the theory enriched my translations.

This was a really great course, with great readings and fun assignments. My only suggestion would be to give more class time to the workshopping of translations, as those sometimes felt a little rushed!
The translation workshops and format of class discussions were great.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to another student! It was very well organized to facilitate student learning, and although some of the readings were dense and difficult to understand on a first pass, I think that class discussion and translation practice helped the entire course come together.
Yes! Translation is fascinating and relevant to everyone, so anyone with a remote interest should take this course. Professor Francis is great and the syllabus was too.
Yes, if you are interested in translation!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
